text: 1. Next follows the Uktha 1 . Verily, breath (prâ n a) is Uktha, for breath raises up (utthâpayati) all this. From him who knows this, there is raised a wise son, knowing the Uktha; he obtains union and oneness with the Uktha.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 2 (SBE15): Brihadâranyaka Upan... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Next follows the Ya g us. Verily, breath is Ya g us, for all these beings are joined in breath 2 . For him who knows this, all beings are joined to procure his excellence; he obtains union and oneness with the Ya g us.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 2 (SBE15): Brihadâranyaka Upan... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. Next follows the Sâman. Verily, breath is the Sâman, for all these beings meet in breath. For him who knows this, all beings meet to procure his excellence; he obtains union and oneness with the Sâman.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 2 (SBE15): Brihadâranyaka Upan... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. Next follows the Kshatra. Verily, breath is the Kshatra, for breath is Kshatra, i.e. breath protects (trâyate) him from being hurt (ksha n ito h ). He who knows this, obtains Kshatra (power), which requires no protection; he obtains union and oneness with Kshatra 3 .

text: 195:1 Meditation on the hymn called uktha. On the uktha, as the principal part in the Mahâvrata, see Kaush. Up. III, 3; Ait. Âr. II, 1, 2. The uktha, yagus, sâman, &c. are here represented as forms under which prâ n a or life, and indirectly Brahman, is to be meditated on.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 195:2 Without life or breath nothing can join anything else; therefore life is called ya g us, as it were yu g us.

text: 195:3 Instead of Kshatram atram, another S âkhâ, i.e. the Mâdhyandina, reads Kshatramâtram, which Dvivedagaṅga explains as, he p. 196 obtains the nature of the Kshatra, or he obtains the Kshatra which protects (Kshatram âtram).
